Your task is to classify if the provided discussion forum post is a feature request or not for Moodle. A feature request is a post where the user asks for new functionality, missing functionality (e.g., features available in other apps), new content, or changes/improvements to existing features in future releases. Posts that are not feature requests include: bug reports, troubleshooting questions, usage questions, configuration issues, announcements, or general discussions.

If the forum post is not a feature request, return NOT_FEATURE_REQUEST. Use the title of the post and the description of the post to make the assessment.
Forum Post: 
Post title: Individualised file downloads
Post description: Hi, I have a class of 40 students and I want to provide each one of them with an individualised assignment handout in moodle. That is, each student should see  their own unique version of a handout pdf file when they click a link. I can upload all 40 versions of the assignment easily enough. The main problem is that I do not want each student to see or access the other students versions of the handout. In other words, each student should only see one version of the handout which is their own, and no one else's. is there anyway to do this? Mike

Any thoughts would be greatly appreciated.

Post title: Would like labels to be recurring each week and is it possible to duplicate content for courses without using import?
Post description: Hello. Is there a way for me to set up the labels in Moodle courses so that they are recurring each week? I am only using Moodle in the most basic manner and would just like to have the labels "Reading Assignments," "Writing Assignments," and "Classwork" each week. I have been manually typing them in because I cannot find a way to have them be a regular part of the course format. Also, I teach two sections of the same class. Is there a way for me to add content to both courses at the same time or do I always need to do it to one and then import it to the other? Thanks so much for any help you can give. My school provides very little help with the platform and I'm so frustrated learning it on my own.

Post title: Possible to Add a parameter to the middle of a URL?
Post description: We're trying to pass the username parameter to a portal script for access to another system. The portal script they want us to use is in this format: https://TheirWebsite.com?TheirParameters&username=USERNAME&FollowedByMoreOfTheirParameters They tell us that the order of the parameters matter. The problem is, if I do a "link to a file" or website resource... the username parameter gets appended to the END of the URL . Is there anyway to get Moodle to pass the parameter to the center? Let me know if anyone has any ideas! Thanks!

Forum Post: 
Post title: How do you control size of resource window when it launches in new window?
Post description: Unfortunately, I am using moodle version 1.5.2, so that may have a bearing on the answer (if there is one).

When a user clicks on a resource link, I have set the resource to launch in a New Window and, according to the instructions, left the fields blank. I had set the windows to open 800x600 but that was cumbersome. Leaving the size fields blank is supposed to open the new window the same size as the window it was launched from.

Here's the (edited) instructions from the moodle:

1. Determine the size window you wish to open.

If you leave these fields blank then the new popup window will be exactly the same size as the window they clicked on to get the popup.

When I set the size to 800x600, the new window always launched as an 800x600 window. However, when the I leave the fields blank, the following happens:

If the browser is IE , then the new window opens to the correct width(!) but the height is very, very small... The new window looks like a ribbon.

If the browser is FireFox , then the new window opens correctly!

In my opinion, this behavior should be the exact opposite: works perfectly in IE, but kludgy in FireFox. If that were the case, the prerequiste for the course would be: Must use an IE browser... Unfortunately, this is not the case...

So, anyone seen this behavior? Any suggestions? Is there a workaround (besides upgrading to a more current version of moodle)?

Thanks for your help...

madea

Forum Post: 
Post title: Launching swf without clicking on 'Direct link to this file?'
Post description: I've added several resources to a course (using the LAMS outline) where each resource has been added as a link to a Flash (.swf) file. When I click on the link, it brings up a window that has an empty image of the Flash file, and a link below it called '(Direct link to this file)'. If I click on this link, my .swf file loads and everything works just fine. The problem is, I would like for the .swf file to be immediately launched when the lesson is clicked on, rather than forcing our students to have to get an intermediate screen that forces them to click something called '(Direct link to file).' Does anyone know of a way to do this... that is, to make a swf file load immediately upon clicking on the lesson ? Or is there a way to modify this intermediate web page that pops up with the '(Direct link to this file)' link so that I can at least provide a better introductory screen for the lesson ? (Also, I tried pointing to the resources to loading an html file that points to the swf file, but after trying about a dozen things to try to get it to resize--all which were unsuccessful--I went back to having the resources point directly to .swf files.) Thanks, Robin

Post title: Resources opening nested inside resource frame
Post description: Dear Moodlers, I have a problem with the way in which auto-linked resources are opening in my version of moodle. I am using the build 1.8.7.20081105. I have the Resource Names Auto-linking text filter enabled and the Filter settings set to filter uploaded HTML files. Apologies, but I'm actually posting in two places as the I'm not sure if this is a Resource issue or/and a Text Filter issue. When (text filtered) autolinks to Resources are clicked, the resource opens up inside the embedded area that the uploaded HTML document resource was occupying rather than the _top level window. This leads to the "double banner" effect which is obviously very ugly and undesirable. Is this a known bug? Or is there a setting I need to enable to avoid this happening? Any and all advice appreciated. My 'other' post about this feature screen grabs of what I'm describing. For that post, please click here . Many thanks, Stuart Anderson

Post title: An idea for the URL resource icon in Moodle reflects the link resourced
Post description: Many are discovering the advantages of using Google Drive/MS One Drive (other) for document storage and serving (including videos and audios).  In Moodle, one uses a URL resource and the icon stays the same for all such resources in a course.   The only way to indicate the URL is on Google Drive/One Drive or other is to use some designator in the link to the resource ... like a '(GD)' for a Google Drive resource. Forum Post: 
Post title: Add link to file: Keep navigation behavior is going to change
Post description: Hi, following http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-20320 issue, the behaviors of "Keep page navigation visible on the same page" are going to be changed: - The "Keep page navigation visible on the same page" option will concern any file type. (at this moment it works as explained into the Moodledocs : http://docs.moodle.org/en/File_or_website_link#Keep_page_navigation_visible_on_the_same_page ) - if you choose "No menu" or "Frame menu", the resource will be managed by the user browser. For example on a Mac, MP3 files will be played by Quicktime with these options. - if you choose "Menu without frame", the resource will be displayed into an object tag. The tag is created following the file extension. For example, MP3 will be played by the Moodle flash player with this option. Please test the patch and let us know your opinion, Thanks, Jerome Related post: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=132906#p582930

Post title: PDF Download Issue in Android Browser
Post description: I am setting up a Moodle Site and most (if not all) of our users will be using an Android Phone. For the most part, Moodle has worked great on a mobile phone (using HTC Incredible). I've only made a few changes to the default theme, and in general, Moodle looks great as long as the phone is in Lanscape Mode. The last thing I plan to do is use browser detection and increase the font size in a few places (load alternate CSS ). So far, the only issue that I can't seem to work around deals with PDF downloads. Here are the scenarios - all using the Resource Module "Link to a file or website" : 1) Force Download CHECKED - After the link is tapped, the user is prompted with the message "The content is not support on the phone. No application can be found to open this file. Do you still want to download it?" The next options are to "Download" or "Exit". If you click download, the file downloads, but when you try to open the file, the file does not open. You can browse to the file using the PDF Reader and then open. 2) Force Download UNCHECKED - Browser loads loads and appears to redirect to the URL of the file but then just returns to the page it is on. The file does not open or download. 3) External Link to PDF (hosted on the same server , domain , etc.) - It works perfectly! The file downloads automatically and the user is prompted to open in the default application or if there are multiple PDF apps, then the user can pick which app to use. I would prefer for the course creator to be able to use the built-in upload /file manager and all that the resource module has to offer. Since it doesn't appear to be a server issue, it seems that the code could be edited to fix this problem. Does anyone have any suggestions? P.S, I also have this same issue with the Certificate Module, downloading the generated PDF certificate. This module doesn't generate a link but instead, a form button that the user clicks on. There are no settings - so I haven't been able to try anything else with it, but I plan on making a post in its forum.

Forum Post: 
Post title: 1.8 Resource-Forced Summaries
Post description: I can't find any way to disable this in the Resource settings or the roles system, unless I'm just not finding this setting, it seems like a bug in 1.8 as this isn't mentioned as an intentional feature in the 1.8 release notes. http://docs.moodle.org/en/Category:Moodle_1.8 http://docs.moodle.org/en/Release_Notes#Moodle_1.8 Why folks might not want this as a feature: If you do a good job of writing a summary, it can take a good deal of time, and faculty like to do a good job on their courses. Many faculty feel that good summaries will act like "Cliff notes" the students will read the summaries and not read the full articles. It also is a big human resource hit for large sites-if you have 1000 faculty each now spending an extra 3 minutes per resource writing decent summaries, your total cost to run Moodle has just shot through the roof. Suggested solutions: There should be a way to turn this off in the Admin module config along with all the other settings that can be set for resources. Or even nicer, a new resource capability:imakeyousummarize, so that a single site could have some courses where summaries are forced and others where they are not. Anyway, think this is a bug as described above, so I've put it in the tracker as: http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-9485

Forum Post: 
Post title: How to Make an Illustrated Lecture
Post description: I just spent the afternoon playing around trying to create something that I will need for my courses, and that is a way to display illustrated lectures. I wanted a simple way to use the html editor within the resource module to create pages that otherwise look like plain text resources but with a column of images on the left side (which would display a "caption" on mouseover) and text on the right. I wanted the image column to stay a constant width, whereas I wanted the text to be able to be resized if the user resized his browser. Bryan Williams suggested to someone that they might use tables to reduce the width of text in the generaltextbox and this inspired me to use tables to create the effect I wanted as well. I have now created a "template" that simply requires entering the lecture text, the image paths and caption text into the html template. This could even be used offline and then the resulting html simply needs to be pasted into the editor. I have been doing all this with the test moodle account at opensourcecms.com since I don't have my own Moodle set up yet, so I can't show you an example of what it looks like, but I've attached the html with the usage instructions embedded if anyone is interested in playing around with it.

Post title: Program resources
Post description: I know of two cases of external programs being used as "program" resources: webwork and brainstorm. Are there any more? The original code for this was contributed, and I never had much time to look at it. I was just documenting it though, and I feel like I want to clean it up somewhat, including changing some variable names. This would break any current use of the program resource, but will hopefully make it easier to use in future applications. My proposed list of the information to be sent to external applications is: moodle_navigation: current crumb trail as a serialized, encoded array moodle_resource: the resource id moodle_username: current username

Post description: Hi, I notice that when I embed content via the File resource type, it looks better in Firefox and Chrome than it does in IE .  Basically, IE puts a border around the iframe, but more importantly it adds space between the bottom of the iframe and the Moodle footer.  Firefox and Chrome don't waste this extra space, so there's more screen space for the embedded content I haven't explored yet how I might be able to compensate for this difference by using a custom theme, but I thought I'd ask in case anyone already knows how to handle it.

Forum Post: 
Post title: 1.9.4 Resource linking to html file no longer working
Post description: Hello: I publish Moodle content using Moodle 1.9.4, I receive from the instructors.  I do not have access to the Moodle source code or the server which it rests on, it is in another time zone.  I have published all our courses for the summer by using absolute URLs in iframes.  I have made it so I can update the files in one course and all the other courses get updated.  It works great!  So, all resources have the same iframe code to a specific course id.  The students just have to enrollment themselves in the “Master” course and then they view all the resources from the course in their main course. However, I am nervous about the number of students we are going to have and so I want to create a course that has all the files stored locally.  In the past, our first trial with Moodle before I started, everything was on .htm pages and was linked through the resource “Link to file or webpage.”  All the html was appearing without issues, links to other html files in the same classroom were working and pictures were appearing.  Now, if I link to the document that html file is broken.  All pictures only show the alt text and all internal links are broken.  Even past courses, which I have never touched, are breaking.  I wish I could provide you with when it happened.  I would guess sometime around the use of iframes. I use Dreamweaver to make the html file the way I like than I either copy it into the HTML editor or zip the files and unzip them in Moodle.  Any file in the course files section that I “link to” will not work, including composing a webpage and pasting the code.  It seems to only want to use absolute links now.   However the iframe(d) code works fine. If the server holds and there is no problem with the number of users (about 1,200 students, 30 instructors, at any point about 670 students could be attempting to load the same resource at one time) this issue is not important.  I do not know the type of server or OS running.  I have asked repeatedly but I have not received an answer.  However I also am in charge of the backup plan and I would like to have one ready to go when the course starts so that the students always have a class ready to go. I have read threads about the HTML editor breaking because of bad code, the max number of users in Moodle http://docs.moodle.org/20/en/User_site_capacities , and other trackers about html issues http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-10769 . I would like to know if using iframes has messed up my linking to courses or if I have done something incorrectly when creating my classes.  I do have access to the administrator login to Moodle but I cannot see any code.    If anyone has any suggestions on why this is happening so suddenly, please let me know what I need to do to fix it.  Thank you so much in advance!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Import text format problem.
Post description: I recently developed a method of converting courses to Moodle 1.8 from Blackboard 6.3. A problem that i'm having, is that the summary is generated from the first 100 characters of the resource body. This means that if the resource body had some content that starts out like this: "Here is some content. I hope that someone can help me solve this problem because I am having some difficulty with it. Moodle Forums are very active and helpful." Then the summary would look like this: "Here if some content. I hope that someone can help me solve this problem because I am having some diff" You can see that the most undesirable thing is that the summaries end up being chopped off in the middle of words/sentences. I thought of a few possible solutions: 1: Delete the summary from the resources page or force it to be blank. 2: Extend the length of the summary from 100 chars to something larger. 3: Make the summary by reading until the first end of sentence character (period, exclamation, or question mark).

Forum Post: 
Post title: Uploaded resource frame vanishes when upgrading from 1.3x to 1.4x
Post description: I've just tried upgrading my test installation from moodle 1.3.4 to 1.4.2 and have discovered a major problem. All of the courses on my server use uploaded files for the content, but while upgrading to 1.4.2, I have discovered that the navigation bar is no longer displayed by when viewing such resources. This seems to be due to a new feature allowing the user to specify whether or not the nav bar is visible for individual resource, unfortuantly the default for this feature changes the previous behavour of moodle, which showed the nav bar above uploaded pages. The new feature is good and potentially useful, but it really should preserve the previous behaviour as the default. There is no way I can roll out 1.4.2 onto our main server, since this would break every single course on our server and require every single page resource in every course to be edited to get back the nav bar. There are 1000's of such resources and this would take weeks to do ! Is there any way of globally re-enabling the nav bar for uploaded resource without having to spend weeks editing every single resource ? I've looked and can't find any options.

Forum Post: 
Post title: IMS Content Package annoyances
Post description: When creating a IMSCP resource I encountered the following problems: Creating the Moodle resource worked fine; however, when you re-open the settings form, the file name of the IMS CP module is no longer visible. When you are playing the IMSCP module, it always shows a Table of Contents that cannot be surpressed. AFAIK the table of contents is derived from the "organisations" element in the IMS CP manifest. AFAIK it is allowed to have zero organisation elements. Therefore, to get rid of the table of contents when playing the module, I removed the organisation element. The result is that Moodle does not play the IMS CP module at all due to a file error. Best regards

Up until now, once a year I move all course files (lessons, assignments, foro attachments and so on)  from my web server to a backup copy. I need to do that because I have to pay for any extra disc I use.  Besides, I want to keep the courses structure so I can keep students enrolments, grades, etc...which is quite necessary for my organization. That's why I can not delete old courses. My question is, how can I move all those files out of the repository in one go without deleting a course? Is there any moodle function that I can use? Thanks in advance.

Post title: Control size of NEW resource window when lauched...
Post description: Unfortunately, I am using moodle version 1.5.2, so that may have a bearing on the answer (if there is one). When a user clicks on a resource link, I have set the resource to launch in a New Window and, according to the instructions, left the fields blank. I had set the windows to open 800x600 but that was cumbersome. Leaving the size fields blank is supposed to open the new window the same size as the window it was launched from. Here's the (edited) instructions from the moodle: Determine the size window you wish to open. If you leave these fields blank then the new popup window will be exactly the same size as the window they clicked on to get the popup. Forum Post: 
Post title: Question Marks replacing some characters in htm files
Post description: Good day, We have been experiencing problems with htm files in our migration process from another LMS to Moodle (applies only to htm files produced in Microsoft Word or PowerPoint).  Question marks are appearing instead of long dashes,  single quotes (magic quotes I believe they're called), and repeated spaces. In all the posts I've read, the question mark issue comes up for non-English characters when the default Character Set is not set to UTF-8.  I'm wondering if this is our problem as well. Our install is Moodle 1.5.3: Fedora Core 2 MySQL 3.23.58 PHP 4.3.4 mbstring enabled (OK status for all these in Moodle Environment page). In order to test if this is a UTF-8 related issue, I then installed Moodle 1.6.3 on a different machine (running CentOS 4.3). I uploaded a couple of the htm files, and the same problem occurs.  Note though, this second Moodle instance  is not yet UTF-8, since the Environment page mbstring status says Check.  The Environment page also says that the My SQL version installed needs to be upgraded in order to guarantee that all data will be converted to UTF-8 in the future. I'm still new to linux, and have been unsuccessful thus far in upgrading MySql or installing/enabling mbstring (GD also has to be installed/enabled). My question is, with respect to the question marks, can anyone say for sure that this is definitely (or definitely not) a UTF-8 related issue? We have quite alot of these htm files to clean up (a number of work-arounds have been discovered, but they involve processing each htm file, one at a time).  Our hope is that there is some setting to change which will allow all such files to display correctly. Thanks, Lindsay.

Post title: Resources within a web page
Post description: Hi People! Moodle V. 1.9 being used here. I'm in the process of developing a course which is broken down into four modules. From the main menu, a student is given an introductory statement to each module. Each module has been created in a 'topic box' which was created when I created the course. Under the introductory statement is a link going to a webpage created within moodle. Inside the webpage is the module course material, made up of course material, external websites, moodle quizes, moodle assignments, moodle resources. At the moment, I've had to create a Fifth topic which I've called "Course Resource Material - Do Not Touch". In this topic I've created the Moodle quizes and assignments that I have linked inside each of the four modules webpages. My question is this: Is there anyway I can create the moodle resources (quizes, assignments, resource) straight into my Web page (which has also been created with Moodle)? Any ideas would be muchly appreciated!! Thanks, Cory

Forum Post: 
Post title: 2.4.3 Save button would be nice Add'n
Post description: When developing page resources, sometimes, you just need to write, preview, rewrite, ...etc. The current choices at the bottom of the page resource are Save and Return, and Save and Display. There is no button just labelled Save.  Since Save and Display won't run an external macros (like links to MathJax), you can't preview TeX formatted math with that display.  "Save and return" means that you need to return to the main page and in order to return to editing, you must find the small gear icon after scrolling back down to the point in the class that has the assignment. With modern, multi-tab browsers, its time for just a save button.  Then someone in the process of editing and testing would just need to save then then switch to the tab already displaying the page and hit F5.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle Filenames with Non-ascii Characters Running IIS 7.5 and 7
Post description: Hi everyone I struck on a problem today with file names, which contains specific danish characters (æøå). At first a thought this might be an issue with encoding, however the problem lies outside Moodle. After having debugging I found that the function ressource_pluginfile contains a varible called args, wich gets the filename in the URI. If running an IIS with Fast CGI any non ascii characters will be cut of, which will result in Moodle not being able to return the file to the user (file not found error). Microsoft has issue a hotfix for this error, which can be found at following URLs: IIS 7.5 : http://support.microsoft.com/kb/2277918/ IIS 7.0 : http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/en/details.aspx?displaylang=en&FamilyID=c17a72bd-7009-4830-85e0-06290f3b8367 More information about this issue can be seen at http://www.redolivedesign.com/utah-web-designers-blog/2010/10/18/how-to-fix-utf-8charset-problem-with-iis-7-5-and-php-fastcgi/ I hope this post will help others fix the issue, without going through hours of debugging. Best regards /Henrik

Forum Post: 
Post title: File Download stall outs with Snow Leopard
Post description: I thought I'd try asking the excellent Moodle community about this even though it is probably only indirectly related to Moodle but we are seeing students having issues downloading files from Moodle under the following conditions: OS: Mac OS 10.6 "Snow Leopard" Browser: Either Firefox or Safari Connection: Offsite ( a slower connection than LAN speed) Basically, any Macbooks with Snow Leopard on them have trouble downloading files (through a resources module) that are greater than 1MB if they are offsite no matter what browser they use (if they are on Campus the files come through just fine). What happens is the download starts and then gets to 1MB and just stops (stalls out). No error, no nothing. You can try to resume, etc and the same thing happens over and over again. When I look in the Apache access logs I see a successful hit on the file.php URL (200) and exactly 1MB of data sent (almost like the browser sent an ACK command saying they were done). I've checked into all of our time-out settings and nothing seems very low (in fact, the downloads hit 1MB and stop pretty quickly before a time-out could possibly be triggered it seems). The other oddity is that they can go to a non-Moodle section of our portal with a file download repository (just straight URLs, no fancy send_file calls or chunking) during the same session and those files will download flawlessly. So, it seems like it is some combo of how Moodle does file downloading and how Snow Leopard receives files. Any help would be appreciated as I have found nothing on the subject and the number of students who can't access files offsite is mounting. In 1.9, we got a URL such as http://moodle.ac.uk/file.php/40/Hairdressing_2.swf - we'd then do something along the lines of <embed src="http://moodle.ac.uk/file.php/40/Hairdressing_2.swf" /> to paraphrase and it'd work. In 2.2, I don't seem to get this static link to the file - I have tried uploading as normal in the file picker and also uploading in my "private files" block too - the "link location" of the file doesn't seem to work. Does anyone know how I can do this?????  We have literally moved to 2.2 last week, so may be missing a useful plugin or something that may help. If I use "add a file" to add the video - or if use the "Moodle media" button at the top of the label box to add the flash file - I just get a link to it the file, which then opens in a new window, not it displayed on the main page you do when embedding it. Any help would be appreciated!!! Laura

Post title: New Unzip changes URLs???
Post description: I've started using HTML5 output from MadCap Flare. To use this in my courses I do the following: Create a zip file of the output HTML5 folder. Upload this as a file resource to my course. In the resource settings, unzip the file. Set default.htm as the default file. Set Appearance to "Open". And that works great. I can pull URLs from within the package to link to directly and all works as I would hope. Until I need to update the resource. No biggie, just repeat the steps above, selecting overwrite when uploading the new zip. However, the URLs for all the pages change! The first unzip creates the URLs as "mymoodle/pluginfile.php/18282/mod_resource/content/ 1 /" The second unzip yields "mymoodle/pluginfile.php/18282/mod_resource/content/ 2 /" And it keeps increasing that number. That means I have to update all my links every time I update resource. That's a mess. Worse still, the old versions seem to be archived/cached somewhere, so if I don't update all my links, they point to outdated material. Is there any way to stop this? It also happens for file resources that are a single file when you upload a new version. There it is somewhat okay as I can link to the file resource, but with these HTML5 folders, I can't point directly to the file and get my nice skin layout. I'm using Moodle 3.9.12. Thanks, Aaron

Forum Post: 
Post title: Resource: Text bug in Moodle 1.7 fix
Post description: Hi, Today I tried to use a text resource on my Moodle homepage to provide information to visitors. It turnes out that the content is only displayed if the resource is configured as pop-up or without blocks. So I inserted the following lines into resource.class.php under mod/resource/type/text line 91: $course = $this->course; line 92: $resource = $this->resource; line 101: echo format_text($resource->alltext, $resource->options, $formatoptions, $course->id); (this is in the section /// Are we displaying the course blocks?) Hope someone fixes this in the released code.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Change the default pdf files drag & drop into PDF.js files
Post description: ```text
In Moodle 2.9 platform, we use the 
https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_pdfjsfolder
 Module

In the course home page , if a file with a .pdf extension is added by using the " drag and drop" , create a pdfjsfolder resource in the section in which we do drag and drop.
The title of the resource will be the name of the PDF file.
We must create a resource for each added PDF.

If the file has another extension, other than .pdf , add the file as the default mode of Moodle.

If possible, add these modifications in a custom plugin in / local
```

Post title: Opening large ppt files (2M+)

Forum Post: 
Post title: Does add a resource, IMS content package work?
Post description: Hi we have moodle 1.9.1 installed on a Windows server with Apache 2. Does add a resource, IMS content package work on this set up? I can get it so that I can click the browse repository and see the list of items. If I try to preview it I get cannot find it. If I just go ahead and add it and then try to view it I get the requested url ... was not found on the server and the url isn't correct for where the repository is located and can't seem to make it locate it. I have a 1.9.3 version set up did the same to that and this time I get the url looking in the right place but told I don't have permission to view that folder. Clearly if I do the same to both and get two different results for where it thinks the repository is, there is something going on. This is what is making me wonder if it works at all on 1.9.1 Anybody know the definitive answer? If I move to 1.9.3 it seems to be an apache security issue which I have no idea how to fix as it is a folder in a folder that already says we can all view it. I've seen this http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=99290 posting that seems to have a similar security issue, but I'm not using Linux and am not in a position to get scripts written for security that sounds a tad overkill. I'm going through this pain because I want to try MrCUTE and getting IMS content package to work seems to be a pre-requisite. Thoughts and ideas (other than upgrading Moodle) much appreciated.

Post description: Hello. Is there a way for me to set up the labels in Moodle courses so that they are recurring each week? Post title: Updating a resource
Post description: I have added some Powerpoint and Word documents that have been created previously and held elsewhere on the server . I now want to update these documents but I cannot see how this can be done in Moodle. The 'Update this resource' button does not seem to work in the way that I would expect. Ideally all documents would be kept within Moodle and be edited from there. What am I doing wrong? Thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Perhaps answering my own question but will I have to wait for the Document Management System when it will be possible to edit files from within Moodle?
Comment 2: Hi Maxwell, Text and web page resources may be edited within Moodle, however Office
files need saving locally then uploading to the course again. As you
say though, a document management system may provide a solution.
Comment 3: Helen Thank you for your prompt reply. I am just getting started with Moodle and am really impressed with the way it has been designed with teachers in mind.
Comment 4: Regarding the updating of a resource: I run updates on a .pdf file through FTP on a schedule to the location where it is stored in the course files under the moodledata directory. It is used for dissemination of schedules. We noticed that after the schedule was updated, the browser would not present the most up-to-date file. Instead the file which was stored in the cache was displayed. Needless to say, this created problems. Our solution was to place the file in a location accessible through a direct URL address ( http://domain.com/data/file.pdf ). After making the change, the user will now always see the latest file posted via FTP.

Forum Post: 
Post title: How do you control size of resource window when it launches in new window?
Post description: Unfortunately, I am using moodle version 1.5.2, so that may have a bearing on the answer (if there is one).

When a user clicks on a resource link, I have set the resource to launch in a New Window and, according to the instructions, left the fields blank. I had set the windows to open 800x600 but that was cumbersome. Leaving the size fields blank is supposed to open the new window the same size as the window it was launched from.

Here's the (edited) instructions from the moodle:

1. Determine the size window you wish to open.

If you leave these fields blank then the new popup window will be exactly the same size as the window they clicked on to get the popup.

When I set the size to 800x600, the new window always launched as an 800x600 window. However, when the I leave the fields blank, the following happens:

If the browser is IE , then the new window opens to the correct width(!) but the height is very, very small... The new window looks like a ribbon.

If the browser is FireFox , then the new window opens correctly!

In my opinion, this behavior should be the exact opposite: works perfectly in IE, but kludgy in FireFox. If that were the case, the prerequiste for the course would be: Must use an IE browser... Unfortunately, this is not the case...

So, anyone seen this behavior? Any suggestions? Is there a workaround (besides upgrading to a more current version of moodle)?

Thanks for your help...

madea

Forum Post: 
Post title: Uploaded my first resource - mp3 that won't play
Post description: Hello all, I uploaded an mp3 file using "add a resource."  Upon hitting "save changes" or navigating to the resource from the main course page in Internet Explorer, nothing happens.  I see my description at the top but the bottom frame is blank.  When I navigate away from the page, I briefly see an "action cancelled" message in the lower frame but not long enough to read all the text.  When I use Firefox or Netscape to navigate to the resource, I get a pop-up asking me whether I want to open the file or download it.  What do I need to do to get the file to play automatically when you click on the name of the resource? Thanks in advance. Edit - forgot to mention, I am using Moodle 1.6
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I tried again: this time instead of uploading the file into wherever it goes when you upload , I linked to its location elsewhere on my website.  Now, when I add it as a resource using Internet Explorer, I get a pop-up asking me if I want to download the file.  So, it seems that I may have solved part of the problem just by using an archive elsewhere on my website. What do I need to do to get my mp3's to play like this: http://moodle.org/mod/resource/view.php?id=2296
Comment 2: Do you have the multimedia plugins filter activated?  I think it's in /admin/filters.php or somewhere like that.
Comment 3: NOW I do!  Thanks for the tip - I didn't realize I needed to do anything special to get it working. Now it is working as expected in Firefox and Netscape, but I still get a "do you want to download this file" prompt in IE .  Any suggestions?  I've tried the usual - logging out and logging back in again, restarting the computer. If it helps at all in diagnosing the problem, when it does play in Firefox, etc., the player doesn't look like the one in the demo, it is skinnier and grey.
Comment 4: I was looking at my records and I have 1.5, not 1.6, as stated in my first post.
Comment 5: I'm sorry, I'm not exactly a moodle power-user.  I just thought I'd chime in about the multimedia plugin because I had the same problem.  You could start searching the forums for mp3 and "multimedia plugin" or "multimedia filter".  I know when I did that I found info about hacking the look of the plugin.  The hacks looked very easy (I still need to do this myself).  I think the hack amounted to creating a text file that described the colors and sizes you wanted.  You might find a reference to your IE problem as well. I'm sorry I can't be more help.  But now that you know what the thing is called, perhaps you can find the answers.
Comment 6: I've been having trouble replying - so I will just say thanks and mention that I found this post with a summary of the quirks of the mp3 filter when adding mp3 as a resource. http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=43297&parent=198904

Post title: Directory: Files vs. Resources
Post description: Just a couple comments on the Directory Resource: It would be nice if the Directory Resource listed files more like the Resources page than the Files page.  For one, as mentioned below by Sarah, the files popup in a window sans toolbar. And another, although it is nice to have the file size shown, I really do not want my users to see the date last modified.  Alas, I have gone back to simply adding an html resource and adding my file links to the page for my " Directory ".
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Not sure if I should start a new topic on this one, but I'm hoping you're subscribed, Chardelle, and can tell me where the option to build the directory is located.  I may just be thick in the head, but I've looked all over the place.  Some of my instructors are really asking for this sort of thing (I think, since I can't quite get it to work).
Comment 2: Hi Amy, you build a directory by uploading a zipped folder of files, then unzipping it. You can also build a directory from files on your moodle site, by checking their boxes in the file viewer and choosing 'create zip archive' from the pull down. Then you can click this new zip file and download it. Whereupon you could also upload it to a new course, unzip it, and build another directory. It would be nice if the moodle upload form let you upload multiple files (the way Gallery's does for instance) at one time without zipping them, wouldn't it?
Comment 3: Thanks so much, Michael.  Yeah, that multiple upload would rock my world, and really pump up some of the profs I'm trying to keep happy here.  At any rate, however, they're absolutely cranked about the quality and accessibility of Moodle.  Cheers!
Comment 4: The way I read your question is that you want to display a directory, not upload multiple files. To do that, turn editing on, select add resource and then choose DIRECTORY as your resource type. S
Comment 5: Hi Amy, The Directory I was referring to is the added resource that Sarah mentioned.  It's a nice way to combine several documents into one link to try to "clean up" the course homepage.  I wanted to mention that you might like to keep an eye on the development of the new Data Management System: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/view.php?f=352 When this comes it will be the solution to so many things... Chardelle

Post title: Launching swf without clicking on 'Direct link to this file?'
Post description: I've added several resources to a course (using the LAMS outline) where each resource has been added as a link to a Flash (.swf) file. When I click on the link, it brings up a window that has an empty image of the Flash file, and a link below it called '(Direct link to this file)'. If I click on this link, my .swf file loads and everything works just fine. The problem is, I would like for the .swf file to be immediately launched when the lesson is clicked on, rather than forcing our students to have to get an intermediate screen that forces them to click something called '(Direct link to file).' Does anyone know of a way to do this... that is, to make a swf file load immediately upon clicking on the lesson ? Or is there a way to modify this intermediate web page that pops up with the '(Direct link to this file)' link so that I can at least provide a better introductory screen for the lesson ? (Also, I tried pointing to the resources to loading an html file that points to the swf file, but after trying about a dozen things to try to get it to resize--all which were unsuccessful--I went back to having the resources point directly to .swf files.) Thanks, Robin

Forum Post: 
Post title: drag and drop file upload not working for one faculty member's account
Post description: I have a faculty member who can't drag and drop files onto Moodle course sections to upload them. When I am logged in as me or as a different faculty member, I can go to a course, turn editing on, and can drag and drop files onto Moodle course sections with no problems. When I log in as that specific instructor, go to one of his courses, and turn editing on: There is no message saying "Drag and drop files onto course sections to upload them...." as I get when I am logged in as me or as other faculty members. When I try to drag and drop a file onto a course section, no file upload area appears. If I am logged in as him, and add a File resource to the course, drag and drop works fine with the file upload field on the File settings page, and the File Picker also works from the File settings page. Is there a specific account setting that would disable drag and drop to the front page of a course? Thanks. keith landa; teaching, learning, and technology center; purchase college suny
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I did some more testing, and it's actually just one course shell where drag and drop upload doesn't work.  I tested that course space logged in as me or as the instructor, and drag and drop file upload doesn't work in either case. When logged in as the instructor, drag and drop file upload works in his other course shells.  So not a problem with his account as I thought before.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Do you have to purge the cache every time you want to view the URL you are trying to add as a result of scripting (script inserts/updates rows in tables in the Moodle database)?
Post description: I am building an app that inserts/updates rows in some of the tables in the Moodle database . The tables are mdl_course_sections, mdl_course_modules, mdl_context and mdl_url. Yes, as you may have guessed, I am trying to script the action of adding a URL to a section minus writing to the logs. After inserting/updating rows to add a URL, correctly (I believe), I could not see the URL, immediately, after doing a browser refresh of the course page. I realized after doing a purge of the whole Moodle website ("Site administration" -> "Development" -> "Purge all caches"), I could see the URL that I intended to add. Do you have to purge the cache every time you want to view the URL that you intended to add by scripting? (You do not have to purge the cache after manually adding the URL to see the URL.) Thank you.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: No, you should not have to purge all the caches manually. Of course, your script cannot just shove data into the database and expect the Moodle caches to magically know which ones need to be cleared. Your script needs to clear the relevant cache. That probably means calling rebuild_course_cache($courseid, true);
Comment 2: Thanks, Tim. Exactly the answer that I was looking for. You have been ever so helpful.
Comment 3: If you want to purge caches during development you can do it slightly more quickly than via the web page by running purge_caches.php from moodle\admin\cli
Comment 4: Haven't really tried your solution, yet. I assume that this script purges the cache for every course page in the whole Moodle site. Thanks, and if I ever feel the need to try your solution, I will definitely consider.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Basic question: text page vs. web page
Post description: Reading through Rice's Moodle 1.9: E-Learning Course Development , and he gives good reasons for whether or not to upload a file. However, he does not give you reasons for choosing text page vs. web page. It seems as though both are pretty flexible. Why would you choose one and not the other?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Related question: web page vs. wiki. I'd like to make my syllabus into a document with links in it for the web, but I don't know how to do the work that [] does in wiki (where you can then create the page to which [] links. Is there a particular way to do it in the WYSIWYG or do you have to know HTML in order to do that for a web page?
Comment 2: A Moodle webpage doesn't work the same as a wiki in that you can't create another page "just like that" but there is a very useful plug in module called a Book that you can install or get your host to install - and that works very easily where you can just press + to add as many pages as you wish to your basic document. It might be worth having a look at. http://moodle.org/mod/data/view.php?d=13&rid=319&filter=1
Comment 3: Margaret: Interesting question. I just chose web page because I wanted the pages to look as nice as possible (images, font styles, colours, sizes, layout of areas within the page, etc.) and I presumed I would be able to do lot more with web pages than with plain text pages. I have a web design background and I am comfortable editing the source HTML directly if required. I am a relative beginner to Moodle, so my inclination was to jump straight into web pages. As to why I didn't upload files: I wanted students to have a click-through experience. For example, the course is designed in such as way as each page continues the "narrative" -- the links then lead to other web pages, with text such as "let's learn more" or "let's find out how that works", etc.
Comment 4: As far as I can tell, I don't actually think there is any practical difference between a page created using the web page resource type and the text page type set to HTML format. I think this may be a redundant distinction now. Perhaps someone else could set me straight as I've just been trying hopelessly to fathom the difference.
Comment 5: The only difference i have found is that you can change the text page formatwhere as the web page is thestandard HTML editor

Forum Post: 
Post title: An idea for the URL resource icon in Moodle reflects the link resourced
Post description: Many are discovering the advantages of using Google Drive/MS One Drive (other) for document storage and serving (including videos and audios).  In Moodle, one uses a URL resource and the icon stays the same for all such resources in a course.   The only way to indicate the URL is on Google Drive/One Drive or other is to use some designator in the link to the resource ... like a '(GD)' for a Google Drive resource. So ... a proposal ... * An alternate set of URL resource icons for: Google Drive/Docs, MS One Drive, other. * A system wide setting to use alt URL icons ... with pre-selects for Google Drive and/or Microsoft's One Drive, etc. * A setting in a course to use alt URL icons and which set. * When creating a URL resource to such a document/file, option to choose which icon. 'spirit of sharing', Ken
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: This is a good idea in principle. I don't see any need for a new setting. Different icons are just better. It would be a setting you never want to turn off, and unnecessary settings are just bad usability . If possible, the icons should be configurable, and managed using the same screen where you manage the other file type icons. The only difficulty I see is that for other file types, the icons are controlled just by the file extension. Here you would need to look at more of the URL. I don't know if the current API extends naturally to handle that, I have not looked. Note that the current API does use the file extension to determine the icon. For example if you like to http://example.com/file.pdf you get a pdf icon. This is good. I think that even after your change, if you like to https://drive.google.com/file.pdf , it should be a PDF icon. It should only be a Google doc, or Google spreadsheet icon, if you are linking to one of those. Thanks for working on this.

Now: what if I would like to link one topic of my course to this material? I tried to login as administrator, as Course Creator etc, but no way: the only solution is to upload the (same) resource in my own directory/course. But what if my web/ server space wouldn't be unlimited? Briefly: I would like someone to tell me how I could link a resource (such as pdf, doc, html etc) that is not in my own course. Thank you very much!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Unfortunately there is at the moment no single user-friendly solution for sharing resources (not just files) across courses in Moodle. Read MDL-9134 and then vote for it! If the sharing can be planned in advance (e.g., all the courses in the math department will share) then you can use a metacourse for the shared resources. However if you want sharing to be spontaneous (e.g., a teacher in a math course decides to use a file in a colleague's science course), then the shared file must exist in a publicly-accessible place on the Web. I use Site Files for shared files. Unfortunately, teachers do not typically have write access to Site Files. Most people use copy as an alternative to sharing. But copying is not sharing. Not only do you use more space, but as soon as you make a copy, you have two versions to maintain.
Comment 2: Basically all this will be resolved by the Repository API in Moodle 2.0. I really don't want to hack this into Moodle because it leads to all kinds of other problems. The idea for the future is that we use a separate repository for all user files (the respository can be all kinds of things from Internet hard drives to specialised document repository software) which Moodle accesses via a plugin to give a nice consistent interface. This is the first priority after the Bugathon. In the meantime, even now you can store files externally somewhere and reference them in resources using their URL . It's just more manual and less secure than the repository API will be.

Forum Post: 
Post title: No Editing Tool Bar for a Text Resource
Post description: When I try create a new Text resource, the Summary section has all of the editing toolbar, but the Full-text section has nothing. I have no editing tools for the actual text box at all. Any suggestions? We are running Moodle 1.5.3 stable build. All editing tools are enabled, since they show up in every other module. Javascript is not the problem as the toolbars are all present and functional everywhere else. I'm using IE6 SP2, but same problem with Firefox .
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi, Paul, If you are trying to create a text resource, there won't be an editing bar in any browser. It WILL be there for the web page resource, though. That's just how the text resource is built. If you'd like, you can use some basic HTML tags to do a little formatting, but that's about it. Hope that helps, Art
Comment 2: Personally I have always wondered why this is. In all other cases, Moodle behaves like this: Display the HTML editor unless the user prefers to have a normal textarea. (A setting in your user profile) Display a dropdown box with different formatting choices (markdown, html format, etc...) if there is just a textarea. Why a user has to choose upfront if he/she is going to use the HTML editor when adding a resource? Personally I like the way you can select a text resource and then just use markdown syntax to quickly write a note, but I think it may be confusing to other users to have to choose between a textpage or a webpage (both of which allow links and formatting to be added) and it is not consistent with the rest of Moodle. There must be some other reason?
Comment 3: Art, Thanks. What I do not understand is why the Summary box has the editing tools (when it is only one line of text information), but the actual text box allows no editing. That does not make sense to me. Having the ability to use the editing tool bars for a text box would be helpful. It isn't even possible to do HTML coding in the box. Paul

Post title: Add link to file: Keep navigation behavior is going to change
Post description: Hi, following http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-20320 issue, the behaviors of "Keep page navigation visible on the same page" are going to be changed: - The "Keep page navigation visible on the same page" option will concern any file type. (at this moment it works as explained into the Moodledocs : http://docs.moodle.org/en/File_or_website_link#Keep_page_navigation_visible_on_the_same_page ) - if you choose "No menu" or "Frame menu", the resource will be managed by the user browser. For example on a Mac, MP3 files will be played by Quicktime with these options. - if you choose "Menu without frame", the resource will be displayed into an object tag. The tag is created following the file extension. For example, MP3 will be played by the Moodle flash player with this option. Please test the patch and let us know your opinion, Thanks, Jerome Related post: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=132906#p582930

Post title: Import Resources
Post description: The FAQs say to import activities and resources from another course, use the Import function on the Admin menu. I have an Administration (not Admin) menu, but there is no Import function listed there. Is there another menu that I am missing? Moodle version is 1.95. Mike Hitchcock
Comments associated with the post:

Forum Post: 
Post title: Speed of uploading and running Powerpoints
Post description: We are finding that Uploading a large Powerpoint (1.94mb) times out with a php error referring to a 30 second limit. A 600kb Powerpoint takes some time to upload but then, when used as a resource, it takes a long time to run. If we short circuit the procedure and load the ppt to the Moodle server using MyComputer and hyperlinking it from a document in Moodle then this gives no problem and is very fast. We even tried a 16mb file this way and were impressed by the speed. This seems to indicate that there is something in the coding of Moodle that is slowing the process or it could be our settings for Moodle? Has anybody come across this before and is there a remedy? Thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Uploading through web browser is always much slower than through FTP . The time out is due to your PHP settings (max_execution_time in the php.ini), nothing to do with Moodle. You can set max_execution_time greater than 30 seconds, or have your sysadmin do it. If you are getting this trying to upload a 1.6MB file, it indicates that your server is probably pretty underpowered or is being overloaded. Are you running the server yourself or are you using a hosting company?
Comment 2: Thanks for your prompt reply. We run Moodle on its own dedicated server on our own W2003 network which, when we short cut the process by putting the Powerpoint directly on it without going through Moodle and then preparing a text page in a Moodle course with a hyperlink to it, works blisteringly fast. This must mean that the server is fine but something in either the coding of Moodle or our settings is slowing up firstly the loading and then the running of Powerpoints. Any further thoughts? Thanks

Post title: Links to online bibliographic databases
Post description: Hi How are people handling links to fulltext articles in subscription based bibliographic databases or ejournals? We use ezproxy to enable off-campus users to use IP based authentication for these databases, but we have to instruct teaching staff to add the ezproxy prefix to all the URLs they create for articles in ProQuest, Ebsco etc Is anyone else dealing with this issue or use an alternative method to allow direct linking to online articles? Cheers David
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: On EBSCO databases, it is possible to make the permanent article/journal/search URLs automatically embed your EZ Proxy information. This means the student can click an article link from home, and provided they have logged into Moodle, the link will automatically authenticate with the EZ Proxy and take them to that article. Here is the link on the EBSCO support page: http://support.epnet.com/knowledge_base/detail.php?id=1376

Post title: Jmol resource and filter in Moodle 1.9
Post description: I tried this in Moodle 1.9, and got the black Java "box" with the text "Atoms Off " etc at the bottom, but nothing displayed. Instead, this error message in the Java region: java.security.AccessControlException: access denied (java.net.SocketPermission <IP address>) I turned up debugging info, and got this additional output: Notice : Undefined variable: querystring in .../moodle/mod/ resource /type/jmol/resource.class.php on line 164 Notice : Undefined property: resource_jmol::$navigation in .../moodle/mod/resource/type/jmol/resource.class.php on line 178 print_header() was sent a string as 3rd ( Water Molecules ) parameter. This is deprecated in favour of an array built by build_navigation(). Please upgrade your code. line 2388 of lib/weblib.php: call to debugging() line 178 of mod/resource/type/jmol/resource.class.php: call to print_header() line 40 of mod/resource/view.php: call to resource_jmol->display() Navigation needs to be updated to use build_navigation() line 3577 of lib/weblib.php: call to debugging() line 90 of theme/wood_custom_corners/header.html: call to print_navigation() line 2588 of lib/weblib.php: call to include() line 178 of mod/resource/type/jmol/resource.class.php: call to print_header() line 40 of mod/resource/view.php: call to resource_jmol->display() EDIT: Strange, it is working now in 1.9!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Strange - it is working now in 1.9!
Comment 2: I posted that Jmol initially dod not work, then that it started working, on one PC. Now, on another PC it is NOT working. The problem PC description: OS: Windows XP with automatic updates Java : Java 6 update 5 browsers in which JMol resource / filter fails: IE 7 Firefox 3 beta 5 Firefox 2 ltest as of 5/5/2008 browsers in which JMol resource / filter works: Opera 9.26 Moodle: version 1.9 The problem: The initial orange Java coffe cup displays, but that's as far as it gets. Unfortunately, I don't have the info for the other PC on which it worked, but it did work in Firefox 3 beta 5 on that other PC. Perhaps it had a different (probably older) version of Java.
Comment 3: Correction. In a previous post I wrote "The initial orange Java coffe cup displays, but that's as far as it gets." well, in Firefox 2, it starated out that way. I came back after a few hours and the Java region was black. Right-clicking gave the jmol menu. But there was nothing displayed - just solid black.
Comment 4: Hi Joe I have sometimes had similar symptoms, and not entirely got to the bottom of things. Seems to be a particular issue with Java 1.6 which is more 'secure' than earlier versions and grumbles about writing/overwriting files in the applet cache. Possible solutions are: refreshing the page clearing browser cache from the Java Console (Java icon bottom right on Windows) set the cache size as 0 downgrading to Java 1.5 I have also had similar symptoms, on machines where my user area quota had reached its limit, so there was no room to download the applet!
Comment 5: ...got timed out whilst editing this reply the third bullet should say... from the Java Control Panel (Java icon bottom right on Windows) set the temporary file size as 0 (counterintuitive? but seems to get rid of the security error). I also *think* it happens if you have just upgraded Jmol or are viewing pages with different versions of the Jmol applet e.g. if you have different versions of Jmol in the filter and resource. I tend to keep both updated with the latest stable Jmol applet (currently 11.4.2). Any Java gurus out there may be able to give more precise explanations/fixes. I am very aware that this impacts the usability of the Jmol resource and filter. As part of a general review and update, I'm considering the workaround, used on the http://jmol.sf.net homepage, of initially displaying an image (.jpg) rather the interactive applet. The applet would then be rendered when the user selected the image. This should speed up the loading/display of Moodle pages containing (multiple) Jmols, and also give some meaningful visual content to those without Java. Displaying the applets one-at-a-time should also be better for performance on 'legacy' client hardware. Due to other commitments, this probably won't happen for a month or two - but I'm on the case! Hope this helps
Comment 6: Thanks much, Geoffrey! One thing I noticed was that, although the problem existed with MY site, it does NOT exist with the jmol resources and filters at http://moodle.yeovil.ac.uk/ ! Why does jmol at moodle.yeovil.ac.uk work, even with Java 6 (JRE), I wonder? It is the same browser that gets the errors above from one site, and works with jmol at the other site. What makes the difference? It may be the Moodle version. Of course, it is a combination of factors - perhaps Moodle 1.9 and Java 6, and ... who knows? You mentioned keeping the same version of jmol for both resource and filter. Anyway, thanks for you suggestions, Geoffrey. I started downgrading Java from 6, but today was a busy day, so I dropped work on jmol for other things. I hope to continue that and try your other suggestions also when time permits.
Comment 7: Info Update - the server was extremely slow that day (when jmol got "stuck" at the orange Java display, mentioned in my earlier post), so that might explain the orange region's persistence. It still leaves unanswered the other problem(s) though.
Comment 8: Since updating from 1.9 beta 4 (jmol resource worked fine there) to 1.9+ I´ve got the same problem: java.security.AccessControlException: access denied (java.net.SocketPermission <IP address>) Andi Additional info: Works fine in OPERA Browser.....

Post title: Pdf error using Firefox
Post description: I have been setting up some course prototypes using pdf files converted from Word docs as resources (link to uploaded file).  For awhile I tried various third-party doc-to-pdf downloads and settled on an evaluation copy of Blue Point Light.  Later I got a copy of Acrobat from my school.  All the pdf files display correctly in windows outside a browser.  They also display correctly as resources in Moodle using IE .  But when I try to display the non-Acrobat pdfs through Firefox , I get an error: "file does not start with %pdf-".  I believe these pdfs were made using Blue Point.  I don't understand why the browser would make a difference. It isn't a pressing problem because the files I convert with Acrobat work fine so I just reconvert the old ones, but I wonder if anyone else has run across this or if anyone understands it.  It makes me a little uneasy about using pdf format since many of our students use Firefox, but pdf also has many advantages, so if the problem is predictable and preventable I would like to use pdf. Thanks, Jim Robertson.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I had the same problem in Mozilla and Firefox.  Got an even stranger message in IE (which I don't like to use). I found out that my web host had disabled the php function "readfile()" during an upgrade of their software.  I asked the help desk to reinstate the function.  It fixed it! There is a way to check your Moodle configuration to see what php functions are disabled, but I don't remember how to do it.  Some of the MoodleGurus may know it. Hope it helps. Brent
Comment 2: try using pdf creator, you can download at sourceforge.com I have no problem converting words files to pdf and later openning with firefox.

Forum Post: 
Post title: pdf / images / document size questions
Post description: I've done all sorts of searches and read everything that seemed related without any help.  So the following questions: 1. Can PDF files be displayed as a resource . . . not uploaded but displayed?  If they can, how is that done? 2. How are images inserted?  I built an image, uploaded it and tried to display it but all I got was a raised box with a red x in it.  When uploading the image it did as for an Image URL and Alternate text, which I haven't a clue what those are and haven't been able to find any information about. 3. I have a document, a glossary, that is 15 Word document pages long.  Is this too big to add as a Resource?  Should it be a download for the student instead?  Again, did my searches and aside from getting 6,488 returns of unrelated discussion no help there. Thank you.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Rene, When you ask for PDF files that are displayed (like an image, I suppose), have you tried adding them as a resource (link to a file) and them setting them to be displayed in the same page? That way, when you click on its name, whatever is on the PDF will be displayed on the screen. You can also try doing a print screen of the PDF, save it as an image and then show it on the course page, but that might bring about other problems, since an image doesn't allow for the same things as a PDF (like searching text, copying, editing, etc.). When you choose to add an image you must either select it from the folder you uploaded it to, or browse your files, select the image, upload it to Moodle and then select it. The URL field indicates the place, in Moodle, where the image was saved. Alternate text is the like a tooltip. It's the text that appears when you go over the image with the mouse. The size of a file isn't measured by its number of pages, but by the space it occupies in the computer. You can add it as a resource (link to file) so that the student can download it. Anyway, if it is a Glossary, why not use Moodle's glossary activity instead? You can import the list of terms from a XML file. Resources can be downloaded, as well as displayed on the course page. That is the case for linked files, and any other files that might be saved in displayed folders, for instance. Hope it helped!

Forum Post: 
Post title: How do I get all my flash output files to work together?
Post description: I hope this question is not too shallow.  I have tried to research it but fall short of finding an answer. I am using Camtasia to produce a Flash (.swf) file named Intro.  It produces these files: Intro.html; Intro.swf; Intro_config. xml ; Intro_controller.swf; Intro_nofp_bg.gif; Intro_preload.swf; mult_choice2.swf; summary_page2 I have been successful in loading to the server Intro.swf and having it play from within Moodle.  However, it does not have the Flash window controls and all the other add-ins like the quiz and preloader files. How do I combine or upload all these to make it play like I built it? Thanks in advance...
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The question was apparently too shallow as seen by the lack of any response.  However, I did not give up trying and I figured it out. In case anyone else has this problem, here is what I did. I uploaded all the created Camtasia files to the server via my ftp to its intended folder destination within Moodle (uploads folder) (***this avoids the uploading size restriction issue within Moodle and PHP***). I then added a resource "Link to a file/website."  Next, I entered the html file that was created by Camtasia and it worked.  I guess the Camtasia folks wanted to make it easy.  I did not realize that the html file contained all the pointers to the other files and that they would retain their correct relationships once they were moved around from location to location. (i.e my computer to the server) Anyway, I am not a programmer type - but more a plug-in-play capable person.  So far Moodle has been great! I hope this is helpful to someone else if they encounter the same questions.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Text vanishes when composing web page
Post description: Please help.  I have built a course in Topic Outline format.  I turn editing on and then go to a topic.  I click on Add A Resource, Compose a Web Page.  I add text to the full text window and save changes.  Bits and pieces of the text I added vanish intermittently, some times on the top line, sometimes in the middle, and sometimes on the text I add at the bottom.  There is no pattern as to which of the text vanishes.  The first word on the first line usually remains, but if I add more words to the first line, those sometimes vanish.  This is sooooooooo frustrating.  Can someone please suggest a workaround or repair?  Thanks everyone.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Do these items vanish in both Edit Mode and Preview Mode? or just Preview mode? If just Preview Mode, do the items show up again when you enter Edit Mode?
Comment 2: In edit mode, and when editing is turned off, it is not there either Thanks
Comment 3: We have tried this on the latest version of IE6 as well as Firefox with the same problems, both on Win XP and Win 2000.  Would anyone please make a suggestion as to what we need to do to resolve this? The only "work-around" that we have is to build and update the web page outside of moodle, which we know is a dopey thing to have to do.  Problem restatement: We go to our course topic, turn editing on, add a resource, compose a web page, enter text, save changed, push the update button, modify or add text, then sometimes the added text is saved and sometimes it vanishes; sometimes the vanishing text is on the same line as existing text, and sometimes it vanishes from a new line.  How should we proceed to resolve this?  Thank you all.
Comment 4: Have not had any relief on this conundrum for two weeks, neither on the forums nor the bug tracker, so we are concluding that its just not that important.  What we would like to do is this: if anyone could let us sneak onto any moodle version higher than 1.4.5, we would test it there, to see if its fixed, before we go to all the trouble of loading up a new version just to find out that the bug still exists.  Who is willing to help us on this matter? Thank you in advance. If you have time to help, email us at emtpny@hotmail.com.
Comment 5: This sounds like possibly a problem with the HTML Editor, perhaps due to a firewall blocking it and you might want to repost to the HTML Editor forum. Alternatively it might have something to do with the character encoding in your Moodle database .  See the following discussion: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=22644
Comment 6: Diane, Why not try the Teacher Play Area on Moodle.org? I suppose the reason you are not getting a response is that the problem has so many variables.  I know for my site (and localhost versions) the HTML editor has been pretty consistent from 1.4.4 to the present 1.5+, though it does regularly clean out certain (predictable) chunks of code when editing or saving.  One also gets surprising results from missing or mistyped tags.  But I am guessing you are describing a more general problem that may be difficult for others to reproduce.  I would suggest checking the HTML editor forum discussions -- there may be something in there that relates to your problem. Good luck, Jim.

Forum Post: 
Post title: PDF Download Issue in Android Browser
Post description: I am setting up a Moodle Site and most (if not all) of our users will be using an Android Phone. For the most part, Moodle has worked great on a mobile phone (using HTC Incredible). I've only made a few changes to the default theme, and in general, Moodle looks great as long as the phone is in Lanscape Mode. The last thing I plan to do is use browser detection and increase the font size in a few places (load alternate CSS ). So far, the only issue that I can't seem to work around deals with PDF downloads. Here are the scenarios - all using the Resource Module "Link to a file or website" : 1) Force Download CHECKED - After the link is tapped, the user is prompted with the message "The content is not support on the phone. No application can be found to open this file. Do you still want to download it?" The next options are to "Download" or "Exit". If you click download, the file downloads, but when you try to open the file, the file does not open. You can browse to the file using the PDF Reader and then open. 2) Force Download UNCHECKED - Browser loads loads and appears to redirect to the URL of the file but then just returns to the page it is on. The file does not open or download. 3) External Link to PDF (hosted on the same server , domain , etc.) - It works perfectly! The file downloads automatically and the user is prompted to open in the default application or if there are multiple PDF apps, then the user can pick which app to use. I would prefer for the course creator to be able to use the built-in upload /file manager and all that the resource module has to offer. Since it doesn't appear to be a server issue, it seems that the code could be edited to fix this problem. Does anyone have any suggestions? P.S, I also have this same issue with the Certificate Module, downloading the generated PDF certificate. This module doesn't generate a link but instead, a form button that the user clicks on. There are no settings - so I haven't been able to try anything else with it, but I plan on making a post in its forum.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I am curious - did you ever find a solution to this?  I am having the same issue with Android Phones.
Comment 2: We had a similar problem here with Moodle 2.1. Any PDF files displayed in a "File" resource in the default setting ("Display: Automatic") were not being displayed on mobile devices, or only in an embedded PDF viewer that did not allow to scroll to the next page of the PDF. A workaround is to use the "Display: Open" setting instead. See also MDL-29987 .
Comment 3: I need to be able to embed .pdf files.  I don't care about mobile phones or older browsers so I hope that you do not choose to completely disable this capability.

Post title: Uploading more than one file
Post description: Hi, I am creating a series of demo videos (in flash)to be included in an online course delivering training on the GIMP. To ensure accessibility for all videos I would like learners to be able to access a link to a transcript of the video on the same page as the video displays. I am linking to my videos as a resource but you can only link to one resource per page. Is there a way to do this? Cheers, Si
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hmm, one way would be to enable object-embed on your site, then embed the videos in an HTML resource, and put a link to the transcript below them. If you have some code familiarity and lots of videos, it might be worthwhile to modify the flash filter to load all swf files at your standard size (800x600 or whatever rather than 320x240).

Forum Post: 
Post title: "No files have been uploaded"
Post description: Can anyone help? When we display a directory it appears to be empty and we get the message: "No files have been uploaded to your course yet", although there are files in the root and subfolders. Strangely, this seems to be a phenomenon that occurs at random, and does not affect every folder. In the same course we have two folders displayed and one shows the contained docs the other gives the above message. Any ideas? Cheers Wolfgang
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Thanks Wolfgang for your post. I think I should add some more information about our problem. When first adding a resource "display a directory" it performs very well. After saving we are able to display the contents of the given directory. Our problem is, that at a random date (first time it happened was some weeks ago, second time was last week wednesday) it "resets" the resource and clicking it doesn't give you the contents of the given directory anymore - instead the message Wolfgang described is displayed. This problem appears to affect many courses. We could not reproduce this behaviour, but editing the link and saving it restores the normal behaviour that we expect. I hope someone can help, René
Comment 2: It's worth checking that the directory name doesn't contain any nasty characters like the ampersand. For example, if you had a directory called 'Reading & Writing' It won't display the contents as the & confuses things.  If you rename the directory to 'Reading and Writing' All will be well.
